Among the several ferroelectric materials which contains hydrogen bonds, potassium dihydrogen phosphate (KDP) is probably the most investigated. In other words, due to the converse piezoelectric effect a DC electric field applied along the [001] direction should induce phase transitions in KDP crystals similarly to that induced by uniaxial pressure with the force applied along the shear direction. Hence, the main goal of this work is to perform x-ray diffraction measurements to verify the assumption that due to a DC electric field applied along the ferroelectric c-aâ¢xâ¢iâ¢sğ‘ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘ italic-c ADDOP:minus italic-a italic-x italic-i italic-sc-axis, the dipoles rotate around the [010] direction of the orthorhombic structure leading to a change in the local site symmetry of the phosphate ions.

The samples were cut from good optical quality crystals grown by slow evaporation in parallelepipeds of dimensions 6Ã—5Ã—1.5651.5NUMBER:6 MULOP:times NUMBER:5 MULOP:times NUMBER:1.56\times 5\times 1.5 mm33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{3} and oriented by X-ray diffraction . The parallelepipeds faces were orthogonal to the [100], [010] and [001] directions to the orthorhombic structure. Electrodes of silver were evaporated on the large faces which are perpendicular to the ferroelectric [001] direction. A Keithley Instruments voltage supply model 246 was used as the voltage source.

Light scattering measurements were performed using a conventional equipment (argon ion laser and double monochromator), with an experimental resolution of 1 cm-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}. A continuos flow-type cryostat was used to record the Raman spectra at low temperatures, which could be controlled to Â±plus-or-minusADDOP:plus-or-minus\pm 0.1 K. Geometries for the spectra listed in the figures follow the usual Porto notation A(BC)D. X-ray scattering measurements were performed using a Rigaku diffractometer with radiation source of Mo KÎ±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alpha coupled with a low temperature chamber. The good penetration of X-ray beam gives advantage to get diffraction from deeper planes, avoiding the non uniformity of electric field on surface. The procedure used in the X-ray experiments was: first, the crystal was aligned using the (440) reflection of paraelectric phase and then cooled down to ferroelectric phase where during the transition, the reciprocal lattice points of (800) and (080) reflections appear satisfying the diffraction conditions of the orthorhombic structure with the C2â¢vsubscriptğ¶2ğ‘£italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 italic-v POSTSUBSCRIPT:endC_{2v} factor group.

However, for E=5ğ¸5italic-E RELOP:equals NUMBER:5E=5 kV/cm , we observe qualitative modifications in the Raman spectra. For B1subscriptğµ1italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endB_{1} symmetry, as shown in Fig. 1(b), we observe an inversion in the intensity of the peaks oscillating at around 200 and 500 cm-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}. Since the symmetries A1subscriptğ´1italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endA_{1} and B1subscriptğµ1italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endB_{1} are unidimensional , the modifications exhibit by the Raman spectra are an evidence that due to the DC electric field the C2â¢v19superscriptsubscriptğ¶2ğ‘£19italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 italic-v POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:19 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endC_{2v}^{19} phase do KDP underwent a phase transition .The modifications observed comply with the symmetry analysis considering the transition from the space group C2â¢v19superscriptsubscriptğ¶2ğ‘£19italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 italic-v POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:19 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endC_{2v}^{19} to the space group C2â¢vâ‰ 19superscriptsubscriptğ¶2ğ‘£absent19italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 italic-v POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start RELOP:not-equals NUMBER:19 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endC_{2v}^{\neq 19}, where the phosphate ion changes its local site symmetry from C2subscriptğ¶2italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endC_{2} to Cssubscriptğ¶ğ‘ italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:endC_{s}. The modifications observed are irreversible once all features seen in the Raman spectra of Figs. 1(a) and 1(b) remain present even when the DC electric field is turned off, and the crystal is maintained in this condition for an arbitrary long time. To go back to the spectra of KDP for the C2â¢v19superscriptsubscriptğ¶2ğ‘£19italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 italic-v POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:19 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endC_{2v}^{19} phase, we must increase the temperature of the crystal over 122 K, and then cool it again at temperatures below 122 K. This irreversibility can be understood as a manifestation of a lowering in the cell potential due to an increase in the dipole interactions. Switching off the DC electric field is not sufficient to overcome the potential barrier created by dipolar interaction. This barrier is overcame only by transferring thermal energy to the dipoles. Due to these facts, we conclude that a DC electric field induces a phase transition in KDP similar to that induced by uniaxial pressure.
